heading: Surgical vs conservative: what is the best treatment of acute Rockwood III acromioclavicular joint dislocation? A systematic review and meta-analysis
text: No literature consensus was found about the best treatment of acute Rockwood type III acromioclavicular joint (ACJ) dislocation. In particular, the advantages and disadvantages between conservative treatment and surgery are not sufficiently quantified in the current literature.

heading: Surgical vs conservative: what is the best treatment of acute Rockwood III acromioclavicular joint dislocation? A systematic review and meta-analysis
text: A systematic literature search was conducted using PubMed, Web of Science and Embase in March 2024. We selected studies comparing surgical and conservative treatment in acute Rockwood III ACJ dislocations. The two treatment methods were compared in terms of Constant score; Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder, and Hand (DASH); American Shoulder and Elbow Surgeons (ASES) score; Acromioclavicular Joint Instability Score (ACJIS); subjective shoulder value (SSV); radiographical findings; reported complications; and return to sports activity. The risk of bias and quality of evidence were assessed using Cochrane guidelines.

heading: Surgical vs conservative: what is the best treatment of acute Rockwood III acromioclavicular joint dislocation? A systematic review and meta-analysis
text: A total of 1844 articles were evaluated, and ten were included in the study for a total of 397 patients. The results of the meta-analysis showed no significant differences between the two groups in terms of Constant score (P = 0.31), DASH (P = 0.52), ASES (P = 0.66) and SSV (P = 0.21), while it highlighted a statistically significant difference in terms of ACJIS (P = 0.00) and acromioclavicular (P = 0.00) and coracoclavicular distance (P = 0.00).

heading: Surgical vs conservative: what is the best treatment of acute Rockwood III acromioclavicular joint dislocation? A systematic review and meta-analysis
text: The results showed no significant differences in terms of patient-reported or objective functional outcomes between the two treatment groups. Nonetheless, it highlights a difference in terms of radiographical outcomes and type of complications. While surgical intervention is able to improve joint reduction, it adds the risk for surgical complications.

heading: Surgical vs conservative: what is the best treatment of acute Rockwood III acromioclavicular joint dislocation? A systematic review and meta-analysis
text: Acromioclavicular joint (ACJ) dislocation typically occurs in young adult athletes and is one of the most common injuries in the shoulder region, with an incidence ranging from 4 to 12%. Its absolute incidence is approximately 3-4 cases per 100,000 people per year (1). The classification most frequently used to describe this type of injury is the one proposed by Rockwood in 1984, which identifies six grades based on the severity of dislocation, the position of the clavicle and the ligaments involved in the trauma (2).

heading: Surgical vs conservative: what is the best treatment of acute Rockwood III acromioclavicular joint dislocation? A systematic review and meta-analysis
text: Rockwood type I and II injuries are characterized by the absence of complete dislocation of the joint and are therefore treated conservatively yielding excellent functional outcomes (3). However, for Rockwood type IV, V and VI injuries, which involve complete dislocation of the ACJ with marked joint instability, surgical treatment is generally preferred (4). Subject to debate is the most appropriate management of Rockwood type III dislocations. These injuries are characterized by complete rupture of the acromioclavicular (AC) and coracoclavicular (CC) ligament complex, causing instability of the ACJ in the vertical plane and potentially additionally the horizontal plane.

heading: Surgical vs conservative: what is the best treatment of acute Rockwood III acromioclavicular joint dislocation? A systematic review and meta-analysis
text: To date, the treatment of grade III dislocation is based on the preferences of the surgeon and the patient, and the age and level of sporting activity (5). The scientific literature is controversial and does not highlight the superiority of one treatment over the other. Non-surgical approaches reduce postoperative complications and enable faster recovery and earlier return to work, but some patients may experience persistent pain and shoulder deformity with poor cosmetic results. Surgery, on the other hand, has much higher complication rates but may allow for anatomic restoration of the shoulder girdle and may be more suitable for patients engaged in heavy manual labor or competitive sports (1).

heading: Surgical vs conservative: what is the best treatment of acute Rockwood III acromioclavicular joint dislocation? A systematic review and meta-analysis
text: The aim of this study was to evaluate and quantify the best treatment to propose to patients with acute type III ACJ dislocation, comparing conservative and surgical approaches in terms of clinical and radiographical outcomes and the incidence of complications.

heading: Surgical vs conservative: what is the best treatment of acute Rockwood III acromioclavicular joint dislocation? A systematic review and meta-analysis
text: A systematic literature review was conducted following the PRISMA (Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-analysis) guidelines (6). The systematic review was registered and allocated in the PROSPERO database (CRD42024536006), National Institute for Health Research, University of York, Center for Reviews and Dissemination. On March 27, 2024, a systematic literature search was performed using PubMed, Web of Science and Embase with the following search string: (acromioclavicular OR AC dislocation OR acromioclavicular dislocation) AND (Rockwood type-III OR Rockwood type 3 OR grade III OR III) AND (treatment).

heading: Surgical vs conservative: what is the best treatment of acute Rockwood III acromioclavicular joint dislocation? A systematic review and meta-analysis
text: Inclusion criteria comprised studies conducted on patients with acute Rockwood type III ACJ dislocations (surgery performed within three weeks of the trauma), studies comparing surgical and conservative treatment, comparative or randomized-controlled trials (RCTs), studies involving humans and studies published in English. Exclusion criteria included studies on subjects with Rockwood type I, II, IV, V and VI ACJ dislocations, preclinical or ex vivo studies, level IV evidence, meta-analyses, systematic literature reviews, articles written in other languages and paper with less than ten patients. Two independent authors (LBP and SF) selected articles meeting the inclusion criteria; in case of disagreement, a third author (RA) intervened to resolve it.

heading: Surgical vs conservative: what is the best treatment of acute Rockwood III acromioclavicular joint dislocation? A systematic review and meta-analysis
text: Two independent authors (LBP and SF) extracted data from full-text versions or supplementary data. Information on study methodology, including study type, level of evidence and year of publication, was collected. Patient characteristics and treatment outcomes were also collected, including the number of patients, gender, age, Rockwood classification, type of intervention, duration of follow-up, postsurgical clinical scores (Constant score, DASH, ASES, ACJIS, SSV), radiographical findings (AC distance and CC distance), reported complications and return to sports activity. The collected outcomes were included if acquired at least 12 months of follow-up. In cases where data were only available graphically, extraction was performed using the WebPlotDigitizer tool.

heading: Surgical vs conservative: what is the best treatment of acute Rockwood III acromioclavicular joint dislocation? A systematic review and meta-analysis
subtopic: Quality and risk of bias evaluation
text: Risk of bias and quality assessment were performed by two separate authors (LBP and SF), and discrepancies were resolved through discussion with a third author (RA). Reviewers evaluated the studies using the revised tool for Risk of Bias in randomized trials (RoB 2.0) for randomized studies and the Risk of Bias In Non-randomized Studies of Interventions (ROBINS) tool for non-randomized clinical studies, as recommended by Cochrane (9). The overall quality of evidence for each outcome was classified as high, moderate, low or very low according to GRADE guidelines.

heading: Surgical vs conservative: what is the best treatment of acute Rockwood III acromioclavicular joint dislocation? A systematic review and meta-analysis
text: A meta-analysis was conducted on clinical and radiographical postoperative outcomes and complication rate regarding conservative versus surgical treatment of acute Rockwood III ACJ dislocation. Variables including Constant score, DASH, ASES, ACJIS, SSV, AC distance and CC distance were assessed using the inverse variance method and expressed as mean differences (MD) for continuous variables. Statistical analysis was performed using the PythonMeta package. The I² metric was used to assess heterogeneity and was considered significant when I² > 25%. A random-effects model was used, and a P value of 0.05 was set as the significance level.

heading: Surgical vs conservative: what is the best treatment of acute Rockwood III acromioclavicular joint dislocation? A systematic review and meta-analysis
text: The literature search yielded 702 articles from PubMed, 785 from Embase and 375 from Web of Science. After removing duplicates and screening, 30 articles were assessed for full-text eligibility. A further 20 were excluded, leaving ten articles for the final analysis. Among these, seven were retrospective comparative studies and three were randomized-controlled trials. In total, a population of 397 patients with Rockwood type III ACJ dislocation was analyzed, with 180 undergoing conservative treatment and 217 undergoing surgical intervention. The sample consisted of 7.3% females and 92.7% males.

heading: Surgical vs conservative: what is the best treatment of acute Rockwood III acromioclavicular joint dislocation? A systematic review and meta-analysis
text: The surgically treated patients had a mean age of 35.6 years, while conservatively treated patients had a mean age of 36.5 years. Conservative treatment involved a sling for 2 to 4 weeks, followed by physiotherapy. Surgical treatment involved various methods: hook plate (69 patients), Kirschner wires (36 patients), Bosworth screw (16 patients), suture-button system (76 patients), and absorbable sutures or synthetic ligaments (20 patients). Postoperative management included a brace followed by physiotherapy.

heading: Surgical vs conservative: what is the best treatment of acute Rockwood III acromioclavicular joint dislocation? A systematic review and meta-analysis
text: Surgically treated patients had a mean±SD Constant score of 90 ± 8.3, a mean postoperative AC distance of 4.3±2.6 mm, and a mean postoperative coracoacromial distance of 10.9±2.3 mm. They reported complications like wound infection and hardware issues in 9.2% of cases and returned to sports in an average of nine weeks. Conservatively treated patients had a mean±SD Constant score of 89.5 ± 8.1, a mean post-treatment AC distance of 9.4 ± 3.8 mm, and a mean postoperative coracoacromial distance of 15 ± 1.5 mm. 22.3% of patients initially treated conservatively were later subjected to surgical intervention and took an average of 7.7 weeks to return to sports.

heading: Surgical vs conservative: what is the best treatment of acute Rockwood III acromioclavicular joint dislocation? A systematic review and meta-analysis
subtopic: Table 1: Characteristics of the articles included in the study
text: This table details the ten studies included in the meta-analysis. For each study, it lists the number of patients, mean age, breakdown of conservative vs. surgical treatment methods (e.g., Kirschner wires, hook plate, suture-button systems), complications (e.g., ACJ deformity, osteolysis, infection), and postoperative outcomes including Constant scores, ASES scores, AJIS, and radiological measurements for CC and AC distance.

heading: Surgical vs conservative: what is the best treatment of acute Rockwood III acromioclavicular joint dislocation? A systematic review and meta-analysis
subtopic: Clinical Scores (Constant, DASH, ASES, SSV, ACJIS)
text: The meta-analysis for the Constant score (7 studies), DASH score (2 studies), ASES score (4 studies), and SSV (2 studies) found no statistically significant difference between surgical and conservative treatment groups. However, the analysis for the ACJIS (3 studies) found a statistically significant difference (MD: -11.93; P = 0.00), with surgery demonstrating a better result compared to conservative treatment. These results are visualized in the forest plots of Figure 2.

heading: Surgical vs conservative: what is the best treatment of acute Rockwood III acromioclavicular joint dislocation? A systematic review and meta-analysis
text: A statistically significant difference was observed between conservative and surgical treatments in terms of both postoperative CC distance (MD: 5.37; P = 0.00) and AC distance (MD: 5.77; P = 0.00). Surgical management showed lower (better) AC and CC distances compared to conservative treatment. These results are visualized in the forest plots of Figure 3.

heading: Surgical vs conservative: what is the best treatment of acute Rockwood III acromioclavicular joint dislocation? A systematic review and meta-analysis
topic: Risk of bias and quality of evidence
text: The evaluation using the RoB 2.0 tool for randomized trials showed three papers falling in the 'Some concerns' category. The evaluation using the ROBINS-I tool for non-randomized studies showed five papers in the 'Moderate' category and two papers in the 'serious' category. Detailed results and graphical representations are shown in Figures 4 and 5.

heading: Surgical vs conservative: what is the best treatment of acute Rockwood III acromioclavicular joint dislocation? A systematic review and meta-analysis
text: This systematic review and meta-analysis did not demonstrate significant relevant differences in patient-reported or functional outcomes between surgical and conservative management for Rockwood type III ACJ dislocations. However, significant differences were identified in radiographical outcomes. Currently, the treatment is controversial. Surgical treatment may achieve anatomical restoration and prevent issues like scapular dyskinesis, but conservative treatment can allow for reasonably good functional recovery.

heading: Surgical vs conservative: what is the best treatment of acute Rockwood III acromioclavicular joint dislocation? A systematic review and meta-analysis
subtopic: Interpretation of Clinical and Radiological Results
text: The analysis of clinical scores (Constant, DASH, ASES, SSV) showed no significant difference. However, the ACJIS score showed a statistically significant difference favoring surgery, which could be attributed to the fact that ACJIS heavily weights radiographical and cosmetic evaluation (45% of the score), which are worse in conservatively treated patients. The analysis of radiological data (AC and CC distances) showed significantly better anatomical restoration with surgery. However, the literature is uncertain if this anatomical restoration directly improves clinical results, as some studies show a progressive loss of reduction after surgery without worsening of clinical outcomes.

heading: Surgical vs conservative: what is the best treatment of acute Rockwood III acromioclavicular joint dislocation? A systematic review and meta-analysis
text: Both procedures have complications. Surgical treatment had a complication rate of 9.2% (e.g., infections, hardware problems), while conservative treatment had a failure rate of 17.2% (persistence of painful symptoms or deformity requiring surgery). It is difficult to directly compare these different types of complications. Limitations of this meta-analysis include the moderate risk of bias and low quality of evidence in most included studies, the heterogeneity of surgical procedures and rehabilitation protocols, and incomplete reporting on patients who failed conservative treatment. However, the included patient group was homogeneous, strengthening the results.

heading: Surgical vs conservative: what is the best treatment of acute Rockwood III acromioclavicular joint dislocation? A systematic review and meta-analysis
text: This systematic literature review and meta-analysis compared the outcomes of surgical management with those of conservative management of acute Rockwood III ACJ dislocations, showing no significant differences in patient-reported outcomes and functional outcomes. This meta-analysis highlights a significant difference in terms of radiographical outcomes with the AC distance and CC distance values smaller in the surgical group than in the conservative group. The surgical approach presents some complications, particularly wound infections and hardware mobilization/intolerance, with a rate of 9.2%; on the other hand, the conservative group presented a rate of failure of 22%, with risks of persistent instability and pain.

heading: Acute Rockwood type III ACJ dislocation: Conservative vs surgical approach. A systematic review and meta-analysis of current concepts in literature
text: The most appropriate approach, surgical or conservative, for acute Rockwood type III acromioclavicular joint (ACJ) dislocation is still under debate. In literature, similar results have been reported with both treatments. This review aims to analyze the operative and conservative outcomes of acute Rockwood type III ACJ dislocation to guide orthopedics in daily practice.

heading: Acute Rockwood type III ACJ dislocation: Conservative vs surgical approach. A systematic review and meta-analysis of current concepts in literature
text: A systematic review and meta-analysis were performed according to PRISMA guidelines. A PICOS template was developed. Four databases (Pubmed, Scopus, Embase, and Medline) were searched, and eligible articles were evaluated according to the Levels of Evidence. The methodological quality of the articles was assessed through the ROBINS-I and the RoB-2. This review was registered in PROSPERO.

heading: Acute Rockwood type III ACJ dislocation: Conservative vs surgical approach. A systematic review and meta-analysis of current concepts in literature
text: Five studies were included, with 73 and 110 patients treated with conservative and surgical approaches, respectively. Three outcomes, Constant Score (CS), coracoclavicular distance (CCD), and acromioclavicular distance (ACD) were analyzed. Only the acromioclavicular distance was statistically significant in the surgical group over the conservative one (p < 0.05); instead, the other two outcomes demonstrated no statistical difference between the two groups.

heading: Acute Rockwood type III ACJ dislocation: Conservative vs surgical approach. A systematic review and meta-analysis of current concepts in literature
text: This study demonstrated statistically significant superiority of the mean ACD score in the radiological follow-up of the surgical group compared to the conservative one. A tendency for better radiological and clinical results, mean CCD and CS scores, respectively, although non statically significant, was reported in the surgical group. High-quality randomized controlled clinical trials should help determine the most appropriate treatment for acute Rockwood type III ACJ dislocations.

heading: Acute Rockwood type III ACJ dislocation: Conservative vs surgical approach. A systematic review and meta-analysis of current concepts in literature
text: Acromioclavicular joint (ACJ) dislocation is a common injury in orthopedic care. It is estimated to represent about 10% of all injuries to the scapular girdle, being the second most frequently shoulder dislocation after the glenohumeral one. It usually involves young male patients with direct, high-energy trauma to the shoulder. ACJ dislocations are classified into six different types, according to Rockwood and Young. Type I and II injuries are characterized by rupture of the acromioclavicular (AC) ligaments without complete dislocation of the joint and are generally treated conservatively with a shoulder sling.

heading: Acute Rockwood type III ACJ dislocation: Conservative vs surgical approach. A systematic review and meta-analysis of current concepts in literature
text: Grade IV to VI Rockwood injuries are characterized by complete dislocation of the ACJ with marked joint instability and require surgical treatment. Highly complex and debated in orthopedics is the most appropriate managing of Rockwood type III dislocations. These injuries are characterized by a complete disruption of the AC and coracoclavicular (CC) ligament complex, causing instability of the ACJ in both the vertical and horizontal planes.

heading: Acute Rockwood type III ACJ dislocation: Conservative vs surgical approach. A systematic review and meta-analysis of current concepts in literature
subtopic: The Controversy of Type III Treatment
text: The International Society of Arthroscopy, Knee Surgery and Orthopaedic Sports Medicine (ISAKOS) Upper Extremity Committee in 2014, further subdivided Rockwood Type III injuries into IIIA (stable) and IIIB (unstable) depending on the residual stability of the ACJ. Nowadays, the treatment of Grade III dislocation is based on surgeon preference, age, and patient activity level. Scientific literature has reported similar results of surgical and conservative treatments. Nonsurgical approaches reduce postoperative complications, but some patients may persist with residual pain and cosmetic deformity. Much higher rates of complications characterize surgery, but it may allow an anatomical restoration of the scapular girdle.

heading: Acute Rockwood type III ACJ dislocation: Conservative vs surgical approach. A systematic review and meta-analysis of current concepts in literature
text: This study was performed according to Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA). The Patient, Intervention, Comparison, Outcomes, and Study (PICOS) design was used to classify and answer clinical questions: patient (P), patients who sustained an acute Rockwood type III ACJ dislocation; intervention (I), patients who underwent surgical treatment; comparison (C), patients who underwent conservative treatment; outcomes (O) clinical, functional and radiographic characteristics; study design model (S), Randomized Clinical Trials (RCTs), prospective and retrospective studies.

heading: Acute Rockwood type III ACJ dislocation: Conservative vs surgical approach. A systematic review and meta-analysis of current concepts in literature
text: Inclusion criteria for the reviewed studies were articles about patients undergoing conservative or surgical treatment with acute Rockwood III ACJ dislocation, written in English, studying human subjects, published between 2000 and 2022 with a minimum mean follow-up of 24 months, RCTs, prospective and retrospective studies with Oxford Centre for Evidence-Based Medicine Levels of Evidence (LoE) 1 to 4. Biochemical and in vitro studies, case reports, editorials, book chapters, technical reports, preclinical studies, and review articles were excluded from the search. We also excluded studies with LoE 5 for a better-quality study.

heading: Acute Rockwood type III ACJ dislocation: Conservative vs surgical approach. A systematic review and meta-analysis of current concepts in literature
text: A literature search in four databases (Pubmed, Scopus, Embase, and Medline) was performed. The search included studies published from 2000 to March 2022. The search found a total of 1,360 studies. After excluding duplicates and screening, five studies were selected for qualitative and quantitative analysis. The PRISMA flow chart is shown in Fig. 1.

heading: Acute Rockwood type III ACJ dislocation: Conservative vs surgical approach. A systematic review and meta-analysis of current concepts in literature
text: Each included article was analyzed according to Levels of Evidence (LoE). The methodological quality of the RCT article was assessed through the Risk of Bias 2 (RoB-2). The Risk of Bias In Non-randomized Studies - of Interventions (ROBINS-I) was used to analyze the retrospective studies. This systematic review and meta-analysis were registered on PROSPERO (CRD42022320855).

heading: Acute Rockwood type III ACJ dislocation: Conservative vs surgical approach. A systematic review and meta-analysis of current concepts in literature
text: Data extracted from the included articles included author and publication year, study design, sample size, age, sex, follow-up, surgical technique, conservative approach, Constant score (CS), complications, return to play, and radiographic distances (ACD, CCD). A meta-analysis was conducted on CS, ACD, and CCD outcomes using standardized mean differences (SMD) and a random-effect model. Heterogeneity was assessed using Cochran's Q and Higgins' I² statistics.

heading: Acute Rockwood type III ACJ dislocation: Conservative vs surgical approach. A systematic review and meta-analysis of current concepts in literature
text: A total of 73 and 110 patients were treated with conservative and surgical procedures, respectively. The main demographic characteristics are summarized in Table 1. Both forest and funnel plots favored patients who underwent surgical treatment for all three outcomes considered (CS, ACD, CCD). For the Constant Score (CS), there was moderate heterogeneity (I²=33%), and the overall effect favored the surgical approach but was not statistically significant (p > 0.05). For the acromioclavicular distance (ACD), there was high heterogeneity (I²=91%), and the overall effect was statistically significant in favor of the surgical approach (p < 0.05).

heading: Acute Rockwood type III ACJ dislocation: Conservative vs surgical approach. A systematic review and meta-analysis of current concepts in literature
text: The most appropriate treatment for ACJ Rockwood III dislocation remains controversial. This review found a statistically significant difference in the mean acromioclavicular distance (ACD) between surgically and conservatively treated patients, favoring surgery. However, better radiological results do not automatically imply better clinical outcomes. Other important results were a trend toward better coracoclavicular distance (CCD) and Constant Score (CS) in the operated group, although not statistically significant. Other clinical scores reported in the included studies showed mixed results, with some showing no difference and others (like the ACJI Scoring System) favoring surgery.

heading: Acute Rockwood type III ACJ dislocation: Conservative vs surgical approach. A systematic review and meta-analysis of current concepts in literature
text: The studies analyzed reported various surgical and conservative treatments (e.g., Kenny-Howard splint, simple arm slings, modified Phemister procedure, hook plate). Both approaches have complications. Persistent pain and residual deformity were described with conservative treatment. Mobilization or rupture of Kirschner wires, hematoma, and infections were associated with surgery. Radiographic follow-up showed a higher incidence of CC ligament ossifications, ACJ arthrosis, and osteolysis in surgically treated patients, though these are often associated with good outcomes.

heading: Acute Rockwood type III ACJ dislocation: Conservative vs surgical approach. A systematic review and meta-analysis of current concepts in literature
text: This systematic review has limitations. First, few low-quality studies were included, mostly retrospective case series. Second, there was a wide variety of follow-up durations. Third, different radiological and clinical scores were used, limiting the scope of the meta-analysis. Fourth, various surgical and conservative treatments were performed, preventing a quantitative analysis of specific techniques.

heading: Acute Rockwood type III ACJ dislocation: Conservative vs surgical approach. A systematic review and meta-analysis of current concepts in literature
text: This systematic review and meta-analysis demonstrated a statistically significant superiority of the mean ACD score in the surgical group's radiological follow-up over the conservative one. Additionally, a tendency for better radiological and clinical results, mean CCD and CS scores, respectively, although non statically significant, was reported in the surgical group. Further high-quality studies, such as randomized clinical trials, should be useful to clarify the most appropriate treatment for acute Rockwood type III ACJ dislocations.

heading: Advice after spraining your acromioclavicular joint (shoulder)
text: A sprain means that you have an injury to some of the soft tissues that support a joint, such as the ligaments. The acromioclavicular joint (ACJ) is the join between the collarbone (clavicle) and the shoulder (acromion). You have sprained your ACJ but you do not have any broken bones. This is a common injury.

heading: Advice after spraining your acromioclavicular joint (shoulder)
text: The common symptoms following this type of injury include: Pain straight after the injury, Swelling, Bruising, Difficulty moving the arm, Deformity at the site of injury.

heading: Advice after spraining your acromioclavicular joint (shoulder)
text: You will be given a sling to support your arm; this should be used for two to six weeks whilst the injury heals. Wear the sling during the day but remove it for exercises and personal hygiene. You can wear it at night time if you find it more comfortable but you don't have to.

heading: Advice after spraining your acromioclavicular joint (shoulder)
text: These injuries almost always heal well with time and therefore follow up clinic appointments are not always needed. Occasionally, an ACJ injury requires surgery. If this is the case with your injury, the treating team will discuss this with you.

heading: Advice after spraining your acromioclavicular joint (shoulder)
topic: What should I do at home?
text: Use over the counter pain killers as required. You may find it easier to sleep propped up with pillows, to be more upright. Use ice over the injured area to help with pain and swelling – an ice pack or a bag of frozen peas wrapped in a tea towel can be used for 10 minutes at a time. Avoid lifting and overhead movement for 6 weeks. You should not drive whilst in a sling. You can return to work as soon as you are able to do your normal duties.

heading: Advice after spraining your acromioclavicular joint (shoulder)
topic: How long will it take to heal?
text: Most sprains heal without any problems in six to twelve weeks. However, it may take several months for your symptoms to settle completely – these can include pain or discomfort, stiffness, decreased strength and swelling. There may always be a slight 'bump' at the end of your collarbone at the site of the injury. The injury may take longer to heal if you suffer from diabetes or if you smoke.

heading: Advice after spraining your acromioclavicular joint (shoulder)
topic: How long will it take to heal?
text: For advice on stopping smoking please visit www.nhs.uk/smokefree or discuss this with your GP.

heading: Advice after spraining your acromioclavicular joint (shoulder)
topic: How long will it take to heal?
text: Once the sprain has started to heal some people might be referred to their local physiotherapy department for assessment, advice and rehabilitation.

heading: Advice after spraining your acromioclavicular joint (shoulder)
text: You should try to do these exercises three to four times a day. Unless advised otherwise, you can start them as soon as it is reasonably comfortable to do so. Repeat these ten times each.

heading: Advice after spraining your acromioclavicular joint (shoulder)
text: Stand and lean forward supporting yourself with your other hand. Try to relax your injured arm and let it hang down. Swing your arm slowly and gently forwards and backwards. Swing your arm slowly and gently side to side. Swing your arm slowly and gently in circles clockwise. Continue for approximately 1-2 minutes in total provided there is no increase in symptoms. Remember to try and relax your arm.

heading: Advice after spraining your acromioclavicular joint (shoulder)
text: Bend your elbow as far as you can, hold for 5-10 seconds, then straighten elbow as far as you can for 5-10 seconds and hold.

heading: Advice after spraining your acromioclavicular joint (shoulder)
text: Separate and straighten your fingers. Hold for 5-10 seconds. Bend your fingers at the knuckles. Hold for 5-10 seconds. Make a fist. Hold for 5-10 seconds.

text: If you have any worries or concerns please contact one of the following: Virtual Fracture Clinic Helpline 01225 821668 or Fracture Clinic 01225 825602.

heading: Acromioclavicular Joint Injury (self-management)
text: You have sustained an injury to your Acromioclavicular joint (ACJ). This is the joint between the top of the shoulder blade (acromion) and the far end of the collar bone (clavicle).

heading: Acromioclavicular Joint Injury (self-management)
text: This normally takes between 3-6 weeks to heal, but soft tissue injuries can persist for up to 3 months. Use the sling (if provided) for up to 3 weeks and for comfort only. You may use the arm in the meantime and indeed it is important to keep the shoulder moving to prevent stiffness but not to aggravate it. Follow the management plan outlined below.

heading: Acromioclavicular Joint Injury (self-management)
text: Take pain killers as required. You may find it more comfortable to sleep propped up with pillows. If you are worried that you are unable to follow this rehabilitation plan, or have any questions, then please phone the Fracture Care Team for advice.

heading: Acromioclavicular Joint Injury (self-management)
text: We do not routinely follow up patients with this type of injury. If after three weeks you are not close to achieving full movement in your shoulder please contact us using the details above. We may arrange some physiotherapy to help with your exercises. Or if you are experiencing pain and symptoms anywhere else, other than at the site of the original injury or surrounding area, please also get in touch using the telephone number provided above.

heading: Acromioclavicular Joint Injury (self-management)
text: If provided, wear the sling during the day except for exercises and personal hygiene. You do not need to wear it at night. Start initial exercises. Do not lift your elbow above shoulder height as this may be painful. You may find it comfortable to wear a lightly weighted backpack during this time.

heading: Acromioclavicular Joint Injury (self-management)
text: You may start to discard the sling and begin normal light activities with the arm and shoulder. Increase movement as shown in the Stage 2 exercises. You should avoid heavy lifting for the full 6 weeks. Start stage 3 exercises once you can do stage 2 exercises with no pain.

heading: Acromioclavicular Joint Injury (self-management)
text: The injury should be largely healed, and you can resume normal activity but be guided by any pain you are experiencing. You should be able to carry out day to day activities. More arduous tasks may cause discomfort. Start to lift your arm over-head.

heading: Acromioclavicular Joint Injury (self-management)
text: If you are still experiencing significant pain and stiffness, then please contact us for further consultation.

heading: Acromioclavicular Joint Injury (self-management)
topic: Initial Exercises to do 4-5 times a day
subtopic: Preliminary Exercises for Hand and Elbow
text: If you have stiffness in your elbow or hand from wearing the sling, you may wish to perform these exercises first. However, once they become easy you can start with the posture and pendulum exercises.

heading: Acromioclavicular Joint Injury (self-management)
topic: Initial Exercises to do 4-5 times a day
text: Bend and straighten your elbow so you feel a mild to moderate stretch. You can use your other arm to assist if necessary. Do not push into pain.

heading: Acromioclavicular Joint Injury (self-management)
topic: Initial Exercises to do 4-5 times a day
text: Put your elbow at your side. Bend it to 90 degrees. Slowly rotate your palm up and down until you feel a mild to moderate stretch. You can use your other arm to assist if necessary. Do not push into pain. Repeat 10-15 times provided there is no increase in symptoms.

heading: Acromioclavicular Joint Injury (self-management)
topic: Initial Exercises to do 4-5 times a day
subtopic: Finger and wrist flexion and extension
text: Open and close your hand as shown 10-15 times. Then move your wrist up and down 10-15 times. After a few days, hold a soft ball/ball of socks. Squeeze the ball as hard as possible without pain. Hold for 5 seconds and repeat 10 times.

heading: Acromioclavicular Joint Injury (self-management)
topic: Initial Exercises to do 4-5 times a day
text: Bring your shoulders back and squeeze your shoulder blades together as shown in the picture. Do this with or without your sling on. Hold the position for 20-30 seconds and repeat 5 times provided there is no increase in symptoms.

heading: Acromioclavicular Joint Injury (self-management)
topic: Initial Exercises to do 4-5 times a day
text: Stand and lean forward supporting your injured arm with your other hand as shown in the picture. Try to relax your injured arm. 1. Assist your arm to move slowly and gently forwards and backwards. 2. Assist your arm to move slowly and gently side to side. Continue for approximately 1-2 minutes in total provided there is no increase in symptoms. Remember to try and relax your arm.

heading: Acromioclavicular Joint Injury (self-management)
topic: Stage 2 exercises to do 4-5 times a day - To start at 3 weeks
text: Use your other hand to lift your arm up in front of you as shown in the pictures. Repeat 10 times provided there is no increase in symptoms.

heading: Acromioclavicular Joint Injury (self-management)
topic: Stage 2 exercises to do 4-5 times a day - To start at 3 weeks
text: Keep the elbow of your injured arm tucked into your side and your elbow bent. Hold onto a stick/umbrella/golf club or similar. Use your unaffected arm to push the hand on your injured arm outwards. Remember to keep your elbow tucked in. Push until you feel a stretch. If you don't have a stick, you could simply hold the injured arm at the wrist and guide it outwards. Hold for 5 seconds then return to the starting position. Repeat 10 times provided there is no increase in symptoms.

heading: Acromioclavicular Joint Injury (self-management)
topic: Stage 3 exercises to do 4-5 times a day - To start at 6 weeks
text: When you have regained full range of movement during the above exercises without pain you can start to do the exercises without the support of your other hand; this is known as active range of movement. Then when you have regained your full range of movement without the support of the other arm you can start to build up your regular activities.

heading: Acromioclavicular Joint Injury (self-management)
topic: Stage 3 exercises to do 4-5 times a day - To start at 6 weeks
text: With your thumb facing up, try to move your arm up, keeping it close beside your body.

heading: Acromioclavicular Joint Injury (self-management)
topic: Stage 3 exercises to do 4-5 times a day - To start at 6 weeks
text: With your thumb facing up and outwards, try to move your arm in a big arc out to the side.

heading: Acromioclavicular Joint Injury (self-management)
topic: Stage 3 exercises to do 4-5 times a day - To start at 6 weeks
text: With your elbow by your side, rotate our forearm outwards, keeping your elbow at about 90 degrees in flexion.

heading: Acromioclavicular Joint Injury (self-management)
text: Repeat all these 3 exercises 10 times each, 4-5 times a day. Only go as far as you can naturally, without doing any trick movements to try and get further. This will increase over time and should not be forced.

heading: Acromioclavicular Joint Injury (self-management)
text: If you are having problems progressing with the exercises and have a follow-up consultation booked, please do let the clinician know so that they can review the exercises and refer you on to Physiotherapy if necessary. If you are on an independent management programme, then please contact us using the number at the top of the letter so that we can also arrange physiotherapy for you.

heading: ACJ Injury Grade 3
text: You have a grade 3 injury to the joint at the end of your collar bone.

heading: ACJ Injury Grade 3
text: It normally takes six weeks to heal, but symptoms can continue for three to six months.

heading: ACJ Injury Grade 3
text: Smoking will slow down your healing. We would advise that you stop smoking while your fracture heals. Talk to your GP or go to www.smokefree.nhs.uk for more information.

heading: ACJ Injury Grade 3
text: Your shoulder may be swollen and you will have some pain. Taking pain medication and using ice or cold packs will help. More information is on the next page.

heading: ACJ Injury Grade 3
text: Use your sling for up to three weeks. You can take it off to wash, dress and do your exercises. It does not need to be worn at night.

heading: ACJ Injury Grade 3
text: It is important to start gentle exercises straight away to prevent stiffness. You will find pictures and instructions for your exercises below. Do not lift your arm over shoulder height for the first three weeks. You should not do any heavy lifting for the first six weeks.

heading: ACJ Injury Grade 3
text: You will see a shoulder speciality about three weeks after your injury. They will assess your injury and explain the next stage of your rehabilitation. Please contact us if you have not received your appointment letter within one week.

heading: ACJ Injury Grade 3
text: If you are concerned about your symptoms, are unable to follow this rehabilitation plan or notice pain other than at your shoulder, please contact the Virtual Fracture Clinic.

heading: ACJ Injury Grade 3
text: Wear your sling for the first three weeks. Take it off to wash, dress and do your exercises. You don't have to wear your sling at night. You may find it more comfortable to sleep propped up on pillows.

heading: ACJ Injury Grade 3
text: Using a cold pack will help with your pain and swelling. You can use an ice pack or bag of frozen peas wrapped in a damp towel. Put this on your elbow for 15 minutes every few hours. Make sure the ice isn't in direct contact with your skin.

heading: ACJ Injury Grade 3
text: Try to rest your arm, especially in the first 24-72 hours.

heading: ACJ Injury Grade 3
text: Start these exercises straight away. Try to do these exercises four to five times a day. Repeat each exercise 10 times.

heading: ACJ Injury Grade 3
text:
1. Bend and straighten your elbow. Repeat 10 times. 
2. Bend your elbow to a right angle. Slowly turn your palm up to the ceiling and down to the ground. Repeat 10 times.
3. Open and close your hand. Next, move your wrist up and down. Repeat 10 times.
4. After a few days, hold a soft ball or rolled up socks. Squeeze the ball and hold for five seconds. Repeat five times.

heading: ACJ Injury Grade 3
text: Bring your shoulders back and gently squeeze your shoulder blades together. Hold for 20-30 seconds. Repeat five times.

heading: ACJ Injury Grade 3
text: Stand next to a firm surface. Support yourself with your un-injured arm and lean forwards. Let your injured arm relax and hang down to the ground. Gently swing your arm, making a small movement. Try to do this forward and backward, side to side and in small circles. Aim to do this for one to two minutes in total. You do not need to push into pain. Remember to keep your arm relaxed.

heading: ACJ Injury Grade 3
text: You can stop using your sling. You can now return to light activities. Remember, you should not do any heavy lifting for six weeks.

heading: ACJ Injury Grade 3
text: Start these exercises three weeks after your injury. Try to do them four to five times a day. Repeat each exercise 10 times.

heading: ACJ Injury Grade 3
text: Use your other hand to lift your injured arm up in front of you, as shown in these pictures.

heading: ACJ Injury Grade 3
text: Keep the elbow of your injured arm tucked into your side and your elbow bent. Hold onto a stick, umbrella or something similar. Use your good arm to push your injured hand outwards. Remember to keep your elbow tucked in. If you don't have a stick, hold your injured arm at the wrist, guide it outwards with your good hand.

heading: ACJ Injury Grade 3
text: Your injury should be healed. You can return to normal activities. Do this gradually and be guided by any pain or discomfort you experience. Some heavier tasks may still be uncomfortable.

heading: ACJ Injury Grade 3
text: Start these exercises six weeks after your injury. Try to do these exercises four to five times a day. Repeat each exercise 10 times.

heading: ACJ Injury Grade 3
text: Lift your arm forwards in front of you. Try to raise the arm as high as you can. You do not need to push into pain. If this is too difficult, try the same movement with a bent elbow.

heading: ACJ Injury Grade 3
text: With your palm facing forwards, move your arm out to the side in a big arc. Try to raise the arm as high as you can. You do not need to push into pain. If this is too difficult, try the same movement with a bent elbow.

heading: ACJ Injury Grade 3
text: Start with your elbow bent by your side. Move your forearm out to the side, keeping your elbow bent and near your waist.

heading: ACJ Injury Grade 3
text: I'm concerned about my symptoms and/or I am struggling to return to exercise. Please contact the Virtual Fracture Clinic.

heading: ACJ Injury Grade 3
text: I am struggling with my sling. What do I do? Contact the Virtual Fracture Clinic. We are happy to give further advice or change your sling if needed.

heading: ACJ Injury Grade 3
text: When can I start driving? You can return to driving when: You are no longer using a sling, You can move comfortably and You can control the vehicle safely. Always test your ability to drive in a safe environment first.

heading: ACJ Injury Grade 3
text: How can I get a certificate for work? You can get a fitness for work statement from your GP.

heading: ACJ Injury Grade 3
text: How do I contact the Virtual Fracture Clinic? Call 020 7288 3310
